user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_unlock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /* Restore previous cancellability state */
        pthread_setcancelstate(OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState, NULL);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobalData_t OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal
...
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strerror(status)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No. The fragment strerror(status) does not call a <string.h> function that writes into a caller-supplied buffer and therefore does not itself risk accessing beyond the bounds of any object referenced by pointer parameters. In the supplied code BSP_DEBUG is defined empty so the expression is not evaluated at runtime. A concrete violation scenario (not present here) would be: copying the returned string into a too-small destination, e.g. strcpy(dest, strerror(status)) where dest is smaller than the error message, or using a <string.h> function that takes a pointer/length (memcpy/strcpy/strcat/strncat/etc.) with an incorrect size/length that causes an out-of-bounds write or read.
